metadata.titel_preek: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me? (The Cry of Dereliction)

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God (as Father and Son) enters the state of godlessness and the curse of Sin to liberate humanity from an autonomous, enslaving Power that they cannot break themselves.

subject.identificatie: God (The Father and the Son acting in unity)
tekstueel_bewijs: The Son and the Father are doing this together.
God is submitting to God's own wrath.
God made him to be sin who knew no sin.

object.identificatie: Redemption from the Curse/Slavery to Sin
tekstueel_bewijs: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law
bring us out of our slavery to sin into the service of his righteousness

zender.identificatie: The Triune God / The Law of God
tekstueel_bewijs: God has consigned all human beings to disobedience, that he may have mercy upon all.
that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is positioned as the helpless Receiver/Beneficiary.

tekstueel_bewijs: only he, the Perfectly Righteous One, could break the hold of these Powers
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject, not merely a Helper.
helper.rol_van_geest: External power given through the promise.

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin (as an autonomous Power), Death, and the Curse of the Law
tekstueel_bewijs: Sin is not a misdeed... but an autonomous, enslaving Power.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described as a 'Power' and 'Dictatorship' that humans are 'tied and bound' by, requiring a divine intervention.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The response of the believer to reach out to others in need as a recognition of the Cross.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Service to the neighbor / Reaching out
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical response is explicitly framed as a result of being 'remade' by God's power.

voorbeelden_god_subject: The Son of God took our place.
God made him to be sin.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We do not want to think of ourselves as sinners.
You will already be making distinctions.

voorbeelden: Cursed be every one who does not abide...
We do not want to hear the older words.
It is vital that we understand...
Sin has a grip on you that you cannot break.
Only the power of God is greater...

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the total inability (non-pouvoir) of the human subject and the absolute power (pouvoir) of God.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from the Curse (S2) to the realization that we are in Slavery (~S1), then shows Christ taking S2 to bring us to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ 'becomes the curse' (S2) to exhaust it, thereby freeing the Receiver.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the 'awful way he died' is the proof of the reality of the Curse.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor; humans are described as incapable of self-liberation. The 'engine' of the narrative is divine substitution.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Abraham Lincoln... refused to blame the South.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: In the Cross of Christ he has broken it.
Sin is... an autonomous, enslaving Power.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Lincoln is used as a historical analogy for theological insight, not as a moral ladder to salvation.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats Jesus not as an example to follow, but as a substitute to believe in.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'trembling' comfort; removal of the burden of self-justification.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'Cry of Dereliction' to the 'Curse' of Galatians is logically and narratively seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between the Father's wrath and the Son's willingness is held in a Trinitarian paradox.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The Son of God took our place under the dictatorship of Sin.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the 'promise' received through faith, providing the power to be 'remade'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; Sin is an 'autonomous Power' that humans cannot break.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject. The narrative arc moves from human bondage to divine liberation through substitution.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is a Good Friday meditation where the focus on divine action is appropriate.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'reaching out' at the end is clearly linked to the Spirit's power, not just a new 'Devoir'.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Sin/Curse) is already sufficiently cosmic and heavy.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Program 1) clearly precedes and enables Ethics (Program 2).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in grace-oriented narrative structure, correctly identifying the 'Heavy Opponent' and placing the 'Pouvoir' entirely in the hands of the Triune God.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the Bach and Lincoln illustrations, Greimasian analysis reveals these serve to reinforce the Subject-switch from Man to God.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Galatians 3; semiotics shows how the 'Curse' functions as a narrative actant that only a Divine Subject can overcome.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimasian analysis exposes that even when the preacher uses 'I' (e.g., 'I crucified thee'), the 'I' is the Opponent/Sinner, while God remains the Subject of the rescue, preventing the sermon from collapsing into moralism.

appendices.notities: The sermon uses Fleming Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace' effectively by making Sin a Power and God the only Actor capable of defeating it.
